cells.data:
Javascript

  • Ways to define functions

    Function Declration: function functionName(param1) {}

    Anonymous Function: var functionName = function(param1) {};

    Function Constructor: var myFunction = new Function("a", "b", "return a * b");

  • What is Javascript Event Delegate?

    To bind the event listener to the parent of an html element. The reason for doing this is to easier adding and removing event listeners. For example, li inside ul, to do event delegation. We bind the click listener to ul, and then use event.target.nodeName to find if it's the exact node we want to bind the event to.

    More examples see http://davidwalsh.name/event-delegate

  • Explain how this works in JavaScript

    Function:

    this point to the function itself.

    Object:

    When a function is called as a method of an object, its this is set to the object the method is called on.

    Simply speaking, this is pointing to one upper level of the element in most case.

    Reference: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/this

  • What do you think of AMD vs CommonJS?

  • Explain why the following doesn't work as an IIFE: function foo(){ }();.

    Need a () to wrap the function body and declarations.

    (function foo() {})()

    IIFE: An immediately-invoked function expression (or IIFE, pronounced "iffy") is a JavaScript design pattern which produces a lexical scope using JavaScript's function scoping.

  • What's the difference between a variable that is: null, undefined or undeclared? How would you go about checking for any of these states?

    undeclared:

    • A variable is undeclared when it does not use the var keyword. It gets created on the global object (that is, the window), thus it operates in a different space as the declared variables.

    undefined:

    • Something is undefined when it hasn’t been defined yet. If you call a variable or function without having actually created it yet the parser will give you an not defined error.

    null:

    • null is a variable that is defined to have a null value.

    • undeclared variables don’t even exist

    • undefined variables exist, but don’t have anything assigned to them
    • null variables exist and have null assigned to them

    First, use typeof to check the type of variable
    Second, null == undefined is true, null === undefined is false

  • What is a closure, and how/why would you use one?

    closure is function inside function. Javascript used it to hide things. 

    Javascript only has function scope, so if we want to do encapsulation, closure is needed.

    function Person() {
    var name;
    var age;

    this.showInfo = function() {
        console.log("name:", name, "age:", age);
    };
}

  • What's a typical use case for anonymous functions?

    In callbacks.

    callback is one kind of closure, and used to avoid async in javascript. Also callback is used to pass data.

  • How do you organize your code? (module pattern, classical inheritance?

    I am currently working with Node.js platform, the code is structured in MVC pattern, and used some other patterns, like singlton and factory.

  • What's the difference between host objects and native objects?

    native object: object is a ECMAScript implementation whose semantics is fully defined by this implementation rathan than by the host environment. 

    For Example: Date, Math, eval, etc.

    host object: object supplied by the host environment to complete the execution of ECMAScript.

    For Example: window, document if it's a browser, location, history.

    https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7614317/what-is-the-difference-between-native-objects-and-host-objects/7614380#7614380

  • Difference between: function Person(){}, var person = Person(), and var person = new Person()?

    function Person() {} and var person = Person(){}; are two ways to create function object. 

    function Person() {} is called function declaration

    var person = function() {} is called function expression. And in this way, this function is also a anonymous function.

    These 2 ways both create a class (called Person).

    var person = new Person() create a new instance(object) of Person class.

  • What's the difference between .call and .apply?

    MDN doc: func.call()

    MDN doc: func.apply()

    Examples

    Both call and apply execute a function in the context, or scope of the first argument passed in.

  • Explain Function.prototype.bind.

    Reference: Bind, Apply, Call

  • When would you use document.write()?

    document.write() overwrites everything in the <body> tag. So in almost all cases, you should not use document.write() yourself.

    Only third party would use document.write(). It could be a good choice for third party vendor to use if they do not know what Front-End environment you are using.

    Lucy Bain blog: JS: When would you use document.write()?

  • What's the difference between feature detection, feature inference, and using the UA string?

    Feature detection: detects if certain feature exists

    Feature interface: is a assumption for if one feature exists (or not), the other feature should also exist (or not)

    UA string: UA stands for user agent, which means your browser. An enample:

    Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/39.0.2171.7

    It is used to detect specific version of a browser

    Lucy Bain Blog

  • Explain AJAX in as much detail as possible.

    AJAX is a short term for Asychoronous JavaScript And XML. This technology is used to do data transfer without reloading the whold page because it's asynchronous. To use AJAX, jQuery provides a very simple way:

    $.ajax({
    method: "GET",
    url: "localhost",
    dataType: "json",
    success: function(res) {
        //some stuff
    }
});

  • Explain how JSONP works (and how it's not really AJAX).

    JSONP: JavaScript Object Notation with Padding

    For safety reason, you are not allowed to call cross-domain server from your JS. But you are allowed to receive a script from other server.

    Example of using JSONP:

    <script src="http://cool-stuff.com/api.json?callback=myCallbackFunction"></script>

    Example of JSONP in jQuery:

    $.ajax({
  url: 'http://cool-stuff.com/api.json',
  dataType: 'jsonp',
  success: function(data) {
    console.log(data);
  }
});

    Important Note

    You can only use JSONP in GET method. For other requests, POST, PUT, DELETE you can only use normail AJAX call.

    There's not much you can do if Cross Origin Resouce Sharing (CORS) proxy is disable from the server side.

    Reference:

    Lucy Bain Blog
    W3C CORS Doc

  • Explain "hoisting".

    In javascript, you can use variable before it's defined as var.

    Reference

    Lucy Bain Blog

  • Describe event bubbling.

    Event bubbling happens when user interacts with nested elements, and the event will bubbling (propagates up) through all the ancestor elements.

    To prevent event bubbling from happening.

    $( "button" ).click(function(event) {
  event.stopPropagation(); // <-- this line here!
  console.log( "button was clicked!" );
});

    Lucy Bain Blog

  • Have you ever used JavaScript templating?

    Embedded JS, JSP

  • What's the difference between an "attribute" and a "property"?

    property: JS DOM elements has properties
    attribute: attributes belongs HTML itself, rather than DOM

    Example:

    <input type="checkbox" checked=true/>

$('input').prop('checked'); // returns true
$('input').attr('checked'); // returns "checked"

    Lucy Bain Blog

  • Why is extending built-in JavaScript objects not a good idea?

    http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/104320/why-is-extending-the-dom-built-in-object-prototypes-a-bad-idea

    • Host object may use some of the built-in JavaScript objects, and you never know which object are getting called, so changing the behavior of built-in object is dangerous.
    • You could also have the chance to overwrite some built-in JavaScript objects which you probably do not want to.

  • Difference between document load event and document ready event?

    ready event is called when html document is loaded
    onload event is called later when other stuff, for example, images are loaded

    http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3698200/window-onload-vs-document-ready

  • What is the difference between == and ===?

    == only checks value
    === disables type coresion, so checks the type of var first, then value

  • Explain the same-origin policy with regards to JavaScript.

    For safety reason, same-origin restricts documents or scripts to load resource from other origin. It's a critical security mechanism for isolating malicious document.

    https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Security/Same-origin_policy

  • Why is it called a Ternary expression, what does the word "Ternary" indicate?

    Lucy Bain Blog

    var isTrue = (true) ? true : false;

  • What is "use strict";? what are the advantages and disadvantages to using it?

    MDN Documentation

    1. disable hoist
    2. silently fail error and throw exception
    3. securing javascript
      1. First, the value passed as this to a function in strict mode is not forced into being an object (a.k.a. "boxed").
      2. Second, in strict mode it's no longer possible to "walk" the JavaScript stack via commonly-implemented extensions to ECMAScript. 

  • Why is it, in general, a good idea to leave the global scope of a website as-is and never touch it?

    Lucy Bain Blog

    • harder to read code
    • anyone can update global variable at any point
    • it's possible to overwrite variable

  • Why would you use something like the load event? Does this event have disadvantages? Do you know any alternatives, and why would you use those?

  • Explain what a single page app is and how to make one SEO-friendly.

    Single apge app is a web app which only has one html document. It uses CSS/JavaScript/AJAX to do transitions between views.

    SEO-friendly

    • provide alt attribute for images
    • Supplement search boxes with navigation and crawlable links.
    • Supplement Flash or Java plug-ins with text on the page.
    • Provide a transcript for video and audio content if the words and phrases used are meant to be indexed by the engines.
